abstract.text: Train a machine learning model to classify natural language text.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A text classifier is a machine learning model that’s been trained to recognize patterns
in natural language text, like the sentiment expressed by a sentence.
You train a text classifier by showing it lots of examples of text you’ve already
labeled—for example, movie reviews that you’ve already labeled as positive, negative,
or neutral.
Start by gathering textual data and importing it into an
instance. You can create a data table from JSON and CSV formats. Or, if your textual
data is in a collection of files, you can sort them into folders, using the folder
names as labels, similar to the image data source used in
As an example, consider a JSON file containing movie reviews that you’ve categorized
by sentiment. Each entry contains a pair of keys, the
and the
. The
values of those keys are the input samples used to train your model. The JSON snippet
below shows three pairs of sentences with their sentiment labels.
In a macOS playground, create a data frame using the
framework.
The resulting data frame has two columns, named
text
and
label
, derived from
the keys in the JSON file. The column names can be anything, as long as they are
meaningful to you, because you’ll use them as parameters in other methods.

content.text: Prepare your data for training and evaluation

inlineContent.text: The data you use to train your model needs to be different from the data you use to
evaluate your model. Use the
method to split your data into two data frames, one for training and the other for testing. The training data frame
contains the majority of your data, and the testing data frame contains the remaining 20 percent.
You can use model training parameters to control the learning process. Choose a classifier algorithm type by specifying
the
parameter. The
algorithm trains quickly and performs well
for a wide variety of data. It’s a good starting point algorithm while you’re exploring your data and models.
You can choose a transfer learning algorithm,
.  Transfer learning models
use a pre-trained model as a feature extractor, you specify the
Transfer learning models can take
longer to train, but can improve accuracy because the baseline model has already been trained on a large amount of text
in a specific language.
If your data contains multiple languages, choose either the maximum entropy algorithm
or
the transfer learning algorithm
and set its
to the Bidirectional Encoder Representations from
Transformers (BERT) embedding feature extractor
If your data contains a single language, use the conditional random fields algorithm
or
the transfer learning algorithm
and set
its
to the Embeddings from Language Models (ELMo) embedding feature extractor
Use the
parameter to specify the evaluation data that’s
held out from training your model. During the training process, use the validation data to estimate your model’s
ability to correctly classify new examples. Depending on the validation accuracy, the classifier algorithm might adjust
values within the model — or stop the training process, if the accuracy is high enough. Since the split of your data is
random, you might get a different result each time you train your model.

inlineContent.text: Next, evaluate your trained model’s performance by testing it against sentences it’s
never seen before. Pass your testing data frame to the
method, which returns an
instance.

code: let evaluationMetrics = sentimentClassifier.evaluation(on: testingData, textColumn: "text", labelColumn: "label")

inlineContent.text: If the evaluation performance isn’t good enough, you may need to retrain with more
data or make other adjustments. For information about improving model performance,
see
When your model is performing well enough, you’re ready to save it so you can use
it in your app. Use the
method
to write the Core ML model file to disk. Provide any information about the model, like its author, version, or
description in an
instance.

content.text: Add a Core ML model to your app

inlineContent.text: With your app open in Xcode, drag the
file into the
navigation pane. Xcode compiles the model and generates a
class
for use in your app. Select the
file in Xcode to view
additional information about the model.

abstract.text: Create machine learning models for use in your app.
Metrics you use to evaluate a classifier’s performance.
The fraction of incorrectly labeled examples.
A table of data for training or evaluating a machine learning model.
A collection of terms and their labels, which augments a tagger that analyzes natural language text.
Information about a model that’s stored in a Core ML model file.
A model you train to classify natural language text.
A feature extractor that provides BERT contextual word embeddings.
A feature extractor that provides ELMo contextual word embeddings.
The type of algorithm that a text classifier uses.
A text classification algorithm that uses a statistical model of transition probabilities between words.
A text classification algorithm that uses multinomial logistic regression based on the frequencies of words, independent of context.
A text classification algorithm that uses transfer learning by leveraging a feature extractor to generate embeddings.
The validation data that a text classifier uses.
Computes evaluation metrics.
Measurements of the classifier’s performance on the training data set.
Measurements of the classifier’s performance on the validation data set.
Exports the text classifier as a Core ML model file at the specified URL.
A map of strings in a vector space that enable your app to find similar
strings by looking at a string’s neighbors.
A word-tagging model you train to classify natural language text at the word level.
Train a machine learning model to classify images, and add it to your Core ML app.
Use metrics to tune the performance of your machine learning model.
A custom model trained to classify or tag natural language text.
Predicts a label for the given input string.
Train a machine learning model to tag individual words in natural language text.
Import, organize, and prepare a table of data to train a machine learning model.
Generates two data frames by randomly splitting the rows of a column, which you select by its name, into strata.
